citeinfo.title: Arches National Park Vegetation Mapping Project - Park Boundary

descript.abstract: This is an Arc/Info polygon coverage showing the boundary of Arches National Park, Utah, as of October 30, 1998. On that date, Congress passed Public Law 105-329, expanding the previous boundary by 3,140 acres to include the area known as the Lost Spring Canyon Addition.
descript.purpose: The purpose of this data is to provide digital documentation of the historical development of Arches National Park. The intended use of all data in the park's GIS library is to support diverse park activities including planning, management, maintenance, research, and interpretation.
descript.supplinf: The calculated difference between the Arc/Info coverages of the previous boundary established in 1971 and the 1998 boundary is 3,141.466 acres. This figure varies by 1.466 acres from the officially reported increase of 3,140 acres. The difference can be attributed to arithmetic rounding contributions and/or minor variations in the boundary delineation, and is not considered significant.

attracc.attraccr: The coverage was minimally attributed; the only user-defined attribute is ACRES, the number of acres contained in the polygon. No formal tests were conducted to verify the accuracy of the polygon boundary or the calculated acreage. There are discrepancies between the original report of the acreage comprising the Monument and the acreage calculated on the basis of this digital coverage.

dataqual.logic: Polygon topology was built for the coverage using the BUILD command in Arc/Info 8.1 for NT Windows. No dangling nodes, slivers or open polygons exist in the data.
dataqual.complete: All polygons and arcs are complete and valid.

horizpa.horizpar: No formal tests of the horizontal positional accuracy were performed. See "Process Steps," in this metadata, for additional information.

citeinfo.title: GPS Data for Lost Spring Canyon Addition
citeinfo.othercit: GPS data were collected around the new park boundary using a Trimble ProXL unit. The coordinates were then differentially corrected. The expected accuracy of the data locations is within 5 meters.

srcinfo.srccontr: The GPS data were used to delineate the expansion of the Arches boundary.

citeinfo.title: Boundary of Arches National Park, Utah, from 1971 to 1998

srcinfo.srccontr: The boundary of Arches National Park as it existed from the time of its establishment as a national park on November 12, 1971 was used as the basis for the updated 1998 boundary.

procstep.procdesc: The addition of 3,140 acres in the northeast section of the park necessitated an adjustment of the existing boundary. The modification was done by collecting GPS data along the boundary of the Lost Spring Canyon Addition using a Trimble ProXL unit. The GPS coordinates were differentially corrected, converted in Arc/Info to UTM NAD27 coordinates, and incorporated into the existing Arches boundary in Arc/Info. The software used for the digitization was Arc/Info 8.0.

overview.eaover: The first four items are default attributes internally assigned and maintained by the Arc/Info software. There is only one user-defined attribute: ACRES, the number of acres represented by the polygon. This figure was derived by multiplying the AREA value (automatically generated by Arc/Info in square meters) by 0.000247 acres/square meter, yielding the number of acres.
overview.eadetcit: Contact ESRI (Environmental Systems Research, Inc.) on the World Wide Web at http://www.esri.com for a more detailed explanation of their internal file structure. Contact the SEUG GIS Program for more detail on the user-defined items.

distinfo.distliab:

The information contained in these data is dynamic and may change over time. The data are not better than the original sources from which they were derived. It is the responsibility of the data user to use the data appropriately and consistent within the limitations of geospatial data in general and these data in particular. Any related graphics (if available) are intended to aid the data user in acquiring relevant data; it is not approriate to use the related graphics as data.
The U.S. Geological Survey and the National Park Service gives no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from an U.S. Geological Survey and National Park Service servers and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the utility of the data on another system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data. Mention of trade names or commercial products in this metadata report does not constitute endorsement or recommendation for use by the U. S. Department of the Interior, U. S.
